intro: Fumaria muralis var. glaucescens, commonly known as the blue wallflower, is a flowering plant native to Europe and parts of Asia. It is a member of the Papaveraceae family and is characterized by its slender, branching stems and clusters of small, blue or purple flowers. The leaves are lance-shaped and covered in a fine, powdery coating that gives them a bluish sheen. This variety is often found growing in rocky or wall crevices, thriving in well-drained soils and full sun. Its ornamental value makes it a popular choice for rock gardens and as a decorative plant in horticultural settings.
